001package io.github.ai4ci.config;
002
003import java.io.Serializable;
004
005import org.immutables.value.Value;
006
007import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.annotation.JsonDeserialize;
008import com.fasterxml.jackson.databind.annotation.JsonSerialize;
009
010import io.github.ai4ci.util.Sampler;
011
012/**
013 * Defines parameters for medical diagnostic tests used in epidemiological
014 * simulations.
015 *
016 * <p>
017 * Models key characteristics of diagnostic tests including:
018 * <ul>
019 * <li>Test sensitivity (true positive rate)</li>
020 * <li>Test specificity (true negative rate)</li>
021 * <li>Result reporting delays</li>
022 * <li>Limit of detection</li>
023 * </ul>
024 *
025 * The testing assumes a viral load signal that is normalised but unbounded. The
026 * limit of detection is used to determine the point at which the test can
027 * reliably detect infection. A true viral load at the limit of detection will
028 * produce a true positive rate equal to the test sensitivity, and a true viral
029 * load of zero will produce a false positive rate equal to (1 - specificity).
030 * Very high viral loads will produce a true positive rate approaching 1, but
031 * the false positive rate will remain at (1 - specificity) regardless of viral
032 * load.
033 *
034 *
035 * <p>
036 * Used to simulate test accuracy and results processing in disease transmission
037 * models. Implements statistical methods for calculating likelihood ratios and
038 * applying test noise.
039 *
040 * @author Rob Challen
041 */
042@Value.Immutable
043@JsonSerialize(as = ImmutableTestParameters.class)
044@JsonDeserialize(as = ImmutableTestParameters.class)
045public interface TestParameters extends Serializable {
046
047        /**
048         * Applies diagnostic test noise to a normalized signal based on test
049         * characteristics.
050         *
051         * <p>
052         * Implements a uniform noise model where:
053         * <ul>
054         * <li>Output for zero signal should be &lt; 1 in (specificity) cases</li>
055         * <li>Output for signal at limit of detection should be 1 in (1-sensitivity)
056         * cases</li>
057         * </ul>
058         *
059         * <p>
060         * The noise follows a linear cumulative distribution between: - Point 0:
061         * (1-sensitivity) - Point 1: (1-specificity)
062         *
063         * @param normalisedSignal Input signal (0-1 scale)
064         * @param sensitivity      Test sensitivity
065         * @param specificity      Test specificity
066         * @param limitOfDetection Minimum detectable signal
067         * @param rng              Random number generator
068         * @return Noisy output signal bounded [0, âˆž)
069         */
070        static double applyNoise(
071                        double normalisedSignal, double sensitivity, double specificity,
072                        double limitOfDetection, Sampler rng
073        ) {
074                // TODO: Convert test error to use a normally distributed noise function
075                // this assumes a 0-1 range of signal. all we need to do is look at
076                // a normal with sensitivity / specificity quantiles at 0 and 1, or
077                // what ever the test limit is.
078                return Math.max(
079                                0,
080                                normalisedSignal
081                                                + limitOfDetection * (rng.uniform() - (1 - sensitivity))
082                                                                / (specificity + sensitivity - 1)
083                );
084        }
085
086        /**
087         * Applies test noise to a normalized viral load signal.
088         *
089         * @param normViralLoad Normalized viral load (0-1 scale)
090         * @param rng           Random number generator for noise application
091         * @return Noisy signal value after applying test characteristics
092         * @see #applyNoise(double, double, double, double, Sampler)
093         */
094        default double applyNoise(double normViralLoad, Sampler rng) {
095                return applyNoise(
096                                normViralLoad, this.getSensitivity(), this.getSpecificity(),
097                                this.getLimitOfDetection(), rng
098                );
099        }
100
101        /**
102         * Gets the test's limit of detection.
103         *
104         * @return Minimum detectable signal level
105         */
106        Double getLimitOfDetection();
107
108        /**
109         * Gets the mean delay for test results to become available.
110         *
111         * @return Average delay in days
112         */
113        Double getMeanTestDelay();
114
115        /**
116         * Gets the standard deviation of test result delay.
117         *
118         * @return Standard deviation in days (log-normal distribution assumed)
119         */
120        Double getSdTestDelay();
121
122        /**
123         * Gets the test's sensitivity (true positive rate).
124         *
125         * @return Value between 0 and 1 representing probability of positive result
126         *         when infected
127         */
128        Double getSensitivity();
129
130        /**
131         * Gets the test's specificity (true negative rate).
132         *
133         * @return Value between 0 and 1 representing probability of negative result
134         *         when not infected
135         */
136        Double getSpecificity();
137
138        /**
139         * Identifier for the test type (e.g. "LFT", "PCR", "SYMPTOMS").
140         *
141         * @return The name/type of the diagnostic test
142         */
143        String getTestName();
144
145        /**
146         * Calculates the negative likelihood ratio (LR-). LR- = (1 - Sensitivity) /
147         * Specificity
148         *
149         * @return Ratio indicating how much to decrease probability of disease with
150         *         negative result
151         * @throws ArithmeticException if specificity equals 0 (division by zero)
152         */
153        default double negativeLikelihoodRatio() {
154                if (this.getSpecificity() == 0) return Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
155                return (1 - this.getSensitivity()) / (this.getSpecificity());
156        }
157
158//      default double postPositiveTestProbability(double prevalence) {
159//              double preTestProbability = prevalence;
160//              double preTestOdds = preTestProbability / (1-preTestProbability);
161//              double postTestOdds = preTestOdds * this.positiveLikelihoodRatio();
162//              return postTestOdds / (1+postTestOdds);
163//      }
164//
165//      default double postNegativeTestProbability(double prevalence) {
166//              double preTestProbability = prevalence;
167//              double preTestOdds = preTestProbability / (1-preTestProbability);
168//              double postTestOdds = preTestOdds * this.negativeLikelihoodRatio();
169//              return postTestOdds / (1+postTestOdds);
170//      }
171
172        /**
173         * Calculates the positive likelihood ratio (LR+). LR+ = Sensitivity / (1 -
174         * Specificity)
175         *
176         * @return Ratio indicating how much to increase probability of disease with
177         *         positive result
178         * @throws ArithmeticException if specificity equals 1 (division by zero)
179         */
180        default double positiveLikelihoodRatio() {
181                if (this.getSpecificity() == 1) return Double.POSITIVE_INFINITY;
182                return this.getSensitivity() / (1 - this.getSpecificity());
183        }
184}
